snippet.title: How to stay safe in Rome! - Tips from a local
snippet.description:
Hello beautiful people!

Rome is not a dangerous city overall, but pickpocketing and small crimes can happen so here you have some easy tips to follow to stay safe!

Leave a like if that was helpful!
And consider subscribing if you're planning to visit Italy or Rome!



- - - - - - - - - - 

- INSTAGRAM 
   https://www.instagram.com/romeinside/

- FACEBOOK
   https://www.facebook.com/romeinside/

- 🤗 Join my Facebook group:
https://www.facebook.com/groups/181359322610139/


[Song: Peyruis - Neutral Bay (Vlog No Copyright Music) Music promoted by Vlog No Copyright Music. Video Link: https://youtu.be/CNBV015NL3U]
tags: how to be safe in rome

comments.textDisplay: Avoid the gorup of teenagers from Romania and other other europe countries. Avoid a person with baby. Don't stay near the exit or entrance area of the metro and bus.

replies.textDisplay: please  don't  worry ive been to rome 3 times and i allways get a hotel  not far from the termini,, late at night  don't  go anywhere the opposite side from the Colosseum side thay are lots of drunk and homeless people but ive never  had any bother ,,,,ive walked the streets  until 4 am and its felt safe ,,just don't  act like a victim and don't  carry a bag

replies.textOriginal: +Rome Inside problem is, in a new city (as a tourist) you dont know the 'bad' areas...you literally walk blind

replies.textDisplay: I would say Rome is fairly safe too. Napoli is quite safe for tourists even tho there's a lot of pickpocketing going on there too. I would say that if you apply the same tips I shared in this video in Napoli and avoid certain neighborhoods you should be fine :)
replies.textOriginal: I would say Rome is fairly safe too. Napoli is quite safe for tourists even tho there's a lot of pickpocketing going on there too. I would say that if you apply the same tips I shared in this video in Napoli and avoid certain neighborhoods you should be fine :)

comments.textDisplay: Well she didn’t say you will get shot stabbed or raped , only get robbed I guess it’s reasonably safe
comments.textOriginal: Well she didn’t say you will get shot stabbed or raped , only get robbed I guess it’s reasonably safe

replies.textDisplay:
prezo Shit, I’m sure it isn’t as dangerous as most American cities like D.C. and Baltimore. Most of the crime I’ve seen in Europe pales in comparison. Try going to New Orleans if you wanna talk about dangerous.


Most dangerous thing in Italy is probably Russian tourists! You don’t wanna fuck with those!

comments.textDisplay: Can you talk about eating in Rome and the restaurants, heard a lot of them scam people.
comments.textOriginal: Can you talk about eating in Rome and the restaurants, heard a lot of them scam people.

replies.textDisplay: Just look at the prices first. They must be shown by law.
replies.textOriginal: Just look at the prices first. They must be shown by law.

replies.textDisplay: The staff at a restaurant near the Trevi Fountain tried to shortchange my husband. Of course he caught the error (he watches his money!) and they gave him the rest of the cash back. Just be aware!
replies.textOriginal: The staff at a restaurant near the Trevi Fountain tried to shortchange my husband. Of course he caught the error (he watches his money!) and they gave him the rest of the cash back. Just be aware!

comments.textDisplay: THANK YOU! I'm so scared of Termini Station 😂
comments.textOriginal: THANK YOU! I'm so scared of Termini Station 😂

replies.textDisplay: +Rome Inside e Tiburtina ?
replies.textOriginal: +Rome Inside e Tiburtina ?

replies.textDisplay: No need to be scared. During the day it will look and feel like any normal train station (I haven't been at night). There's even a section with very high-end foodie restaurants that looks like it could be one of the piers in San Francisco, which makes for a really nice place to hang out if you're early for your train. Just keep an eye on your belongings, and you'll be fine.
replies.textOriginal: No need to be scared. During the day it will look and feel like any normal train station (I haven't been at night). There's even a section with very high-end foodie restaurants that looks like it could be one of the piers in San Francisco, which makes for a really nice place to hang out if you're early for your train. Just keep an eye on your belongings, and you'll be fine.

replies.textDisplay: I tried the most delicious croissant on the termini station,  from an indian cafe,  so idk,  for me it was ok :D
replies.textOriginal: I tried the most delicious croissant on the termini station,  from an indian cafe,  so idk,  for me it was ok :D

replies.textDisplay: It's Elissa, not Alyssa yes but don't worry, be happy... Inside the station, for relax and eating delicious meal, go to "Mercato Centrale". It's a new initiative (from 2015), there are different eighteen "comptoirs" with good examples of Roman cooking. This is not a tourist' tramp but at the contrary is a very appreciated place by Italians https://fr.tripadvisor.be/Restaurant_Review-d11666992?m=55593. ps : try "Bonci panificio"; Bonci is the best pizza al taglio maker in Rome (3 pizzerie in Rome)
replies.textOriginal: It's Elissa, not Alyssa yes but don't worry, be happy... Inside the station, for relax and eating delicious meal, go to "Mercato Centrale". comments.textDisplay:
Seems like I was very lucky in Rome. I wore a backpack (but of course all valuable stuff was at deeper pockets and hard to get), I walked alone at Termini at 9-10 pm, and luckily nothing happened to me.
However there were always policemen around who warned me to be careful. I felt so relaxed and fearless until they told me it wasnt safe there. XD
comments.textOriginal:
Seems like I was very lucky in Rome.  I wore a backpack (but of course all valuable stuff was at deeper pockets and hard to get), I walked alone at Termini at 9-10 pm, and luckily nothing happened to me. 
However there were always policemen around who warned me to be careful. I felt so relaxed and fearless until they told me it wasnt safe there. XD

comments.textDisplay: I visited Rome twice, and as very careful as you said.  Very sad that it is that way.  By the way, an extreme contrast would be Tokyo, or Japan in general...you can leave valuables on a street corner and find them the next day!  Oh my goodness!

comments.textDisplay: I agree.  Termini for short periods.  Although it does have a lot of cool shops and places to eat.  If you're stuck there for a while it is accomodating as long as you keep your head up!     Oh Yes, the lower banks of the Tevere is no man's land at night.
comments.textOriginal: I agree.  Termini for short periods.  Although it does have a lot of cool shops and places to eat.  If you're stuck there for a while it is accomodating as long as you keep your head up!     Oh Yes, the lower banks of the Tevere is no man's land at night.

comments.textDisplay: Just spent a week in Rome. I was alert to dangers but always felt safe. But then again, I'm 6 foot 2 and 200 pounds. Maybe older folk and women traveling solo should be more careful.
comments.textOriginal: Just spent a week in Rome. I was alert to dangers but always felt safe. But then again, I'm 6 foot 2 and 200 pounds. Maybe older folk and women traveling solo should be more careful.

comments.textDisplay: Wasnt entirely looking forward to my trip to Rome last year because I HATE being pestered by gypsies and other scumbags that roam these cities. Had a harmless but annoying experience with a fake "attendant" who came over to "help" me do a transaction at a train machine. This was not an employee, just a scumbag rat looking for tips. My rule is that I dont want ANYONE getting close enough to touch me physically. Dont trust people who come up to you and initiate conversations, try to sell you something or ask for money. Be distrustful of EVERYONE in these areas. "Beggars" on the trains holding babies that arent theirs with their hands out to you....avoid them. Avoid the annoying tour hawkers (many are North African and just annoying and pesty)....be suspicious of ANYONE trying to start up a chat with you or who asks you questions, etc. KEEP AN EYE ON YOUR LUGGAGE! Constantly be on the alert. The whole city of Rome is not like this but the big tourist attractions and trains/buses are hotbeds of scams, imposters and scumbags. I made it thru my trip unscathed but wont be returning...there are better parts of Italy.
comments.textOriginal: Wasnt entirely looking forward to my trip to Rome last year because I HATE being pestered by gypsies and other scumbags that roam these cities. Had a harmless but annoying experience with a fake "attendant" who came over to "help" me do a transaction at a train machine. This was not an employee, just a scumbag rat looking for tips. My rule is that I dont want ANYONE getting close enough to touch me physically. Dont trust people who come up to you and initiate conversations, try to sell you something or ask for money. Be distrustful of EVERYONE in these areas. "Beggars" on the trains holding babies that arent theirs with their hands out to you....avoid them. Avoid the annoying tour hawkers (many are North African and just annoying and pesty)....be suspicious of ANYONE trying to start up a chat with you or who asks you questions, etc. KEEP AN EYE ON YOUR LUGGAGE! Constantly be on the alert. The whole city of Rome is not like this but the big tourist attractions and trains/buses are hotbeds of scams, imposters and scumbags. I made it thru my trip unscathed but wont be returning...there are better parts of Italy.

comments.textDisplay:
If you plan to take a train soon, could you do a video showing how you travel through this labyrinth of Roma Termini station..?

So we could get a sense of what it looks like, and see how it might be confusing (labyrinth/maze factor)


Edit: also, if you haven’t already made one, could you maybe do a video discussing potentially dangerous (or at least bad for tourists) places we should avoid?
And maybe like when to (what time of day to steer clear from said places).

replies.textDisplay:
I'll definitely keep in mind the Termini station video!

There aren't really any dangerous places for tourists as long as you don't adventure in the outskirts, but you have no reason to do that so I wouldn't be worried about this! :D

Anyway, if you have any more questions you can send me a DM on Instagram! :)
replies.textOriginal:
I'll definitely keep in mind the Termini station video!

There aren't really any dangerous places for tourists as long as you don't adventure in the outskirts, but you have no reason to do that so I wouldn't be worried about this! :D

Anyway, if you have any more questions you can send me a DM on Instagram! :)

comments.textDisplay: I was in Rome a week ago and I totally understand where you are coming from. We went to termini on a daily basis and there is lots of police so I did feel save, at least during the day and afternoon (haven't been there past 10). There are lots of homeless people and people who try to sell you stuff, don't make eye contact or say no and walk away (that worked for me). At termini and napoli centrale we were warned for pickpockets so we were extra careful. I also read lots of warnings online but for me it wasn't as bad as it sounded online. Don't make yourself scared and enjoy Rome, just be careful with your belongings like in every big city.
comments.textOriginal: I was in Rome a week ago and I totally understand where you are coming from. We went to termini on a daily basis and there is lots of police so I did feel save, at least during the day and afternoon (haven't been there past 10). There are lots of homeless people and people who try to sell you stuff, don't make eye contact or say no and walk away (that worked for me). At termini and napoli centrale we were warned for pickpockets so we were extra careful. I also read lots of warnings online but for me it wasn't as bad as it sounded online. Don't make yourself scared and enjoy Rome, just be careful with your belongings like in every big city.

replies.textDisplay: What did they steal?. There is no such a thing as a safe place in the world. I had my car stolen from a high security car park in London. Every minute cars are stolen in London. I have visited the poorest parts of the world and you can pretty much leave your belongings unsecured and nobody touches it. The world became greedy and dangerous since the financial crashes.

comments.textDisplay: I booked WRH Termini (North of Rome Termini) by accident during the summer, paid too. I am worried it's not safe at night after a night tour. Furthermore, the hotel is said to be on the 3rd level, accessible by security pin on first level. Overthinking but I also scared that someone might follow me up by charging into the lift. Should I change hotel?

replies.textDisplay: Most locals would talk about NYC. Chicago, or LA the same way.  They are pretty safe, just don't be an idiot.  Every single white person in LA knows what's up in Compton, but if someone visited from Rome, you'd have to tell them the city is safe but stay the fuck out of there.

comments.textDisplay: Thank you for your tips. I viewed this video before my first trip to Rome , a few weeks ago. I followed your tips and had no issues. The only rule of yours that I didn't follow was the backpack. I used a backpack but only for non valuables like our jackets , bottles of water, maps etc.
comments.textOriginal: Thank you for your tips. I viewed this video before my first trip to Rome , a few weeks ago. I followed your tips and had no issues. The only rule of yours that I didn't follow was the backpack. I used a backpack but only for non valuables like our jackets , bottles of water, maps etc.

comments.textDisplay: I wear cargo pants with button or zippered pockets whilst travelling. I also put small padlocks on my backpack. This won't stop pickpockets, but they'll probably look for easier targets.
comments.textOriginal: I wear cargo pants with button or zippered pockets whilst travelling. I also put small padlocks on my backpack. This won't stop pickpockets, but they'll probably look for easier targets.

comments.textDisplay:
Every capital city in the world where there are a lot of tourists has a lot of nasty people waiting to rob you especially if you are vunerable looking they will not attempt to rob you if are young big and strong
looking as all cowards do they prey on easy looking targets where they expect little resistance. Most main rail stations in the world seem to attract undesirable people hanging around. Always be alert.
stay close to a lot of people look around to see if there are any security or police in case you need them. Most of all don't let your fear of bad people dominate your stay in that country youre there to enjoy yourself to the utmost and come away loving your visit and wanting to return again. Which I know you will if you are visiting Rome.

comments.textDisplay: I like your English pronunciation by the way..Anyways, I have been to beautiful Rome 23 times and will be in Rome soon, January 31st. Rome is relatively safe, but it is getting more crowded and yes, there are Street hustlers. My favorite place to eat is at GIGLIO near the Opera House, Via Torino,just off Via Nazionale, and La Matriciana near the Opera House also. So thank you so much for providing this video, I am sure that it helped many people.

comments.textDisplay:
Rome is fairly safe for tourists and locals. Avoid the bus, don't look like an obvious tourist etc. Wear a money belt, keep everything in the front. Learn a few words of italian (they do appreciate it)

Full confession though-I had my DSLR around my neck over the Christmas holidays and no one bothered me. I even did this in Naples at night and got away with it. Not recommended for everyone obviously. The fact that i had my wife and kids with me probably changed the situation. Not sure.

Anyways....enjoy Rome! Everytime we go back it is beautiful, regardless of season!
comments.textOriginal:

Anyways....enjoy Rome! Everytime we go back it is beautiful, regardless of season!

comments.textDisplay: Whats in the outskirts of Rome? I once saw a very beautiful woman on the internet called Ciara she was from a suburb of Rome. Why is it dangerous in the suburbs?
comments.textOriginal: Whats in the outskirts of Rome? I once saw a very beautiful woman on the internet called Ciara she was from a suburb of Rome. Why is it dangerous in the suburbs?

replies.textDisplay: Hello, there really isn't much to see in the suburbs of Rome from a touristic point of view. There is one suburb I know of called La Prenestina that you avoid (nothing to see anyway). Some of the suburbs are fine but, as a tourist/ traveler there is tons to see in the centre. I lived in Rome for 2 years and nothing happened to me. If you go, you keep your wits about you. My niece is going to Rome soon and I pretty much gave her the same warnings as this vid. I would add, not to let some dude dressed as an ancient Roman soldier take your pic or be in a pic with you (around the Colosseum) - they will charge you 50 euro. And keep your distance from gypsies no matter what - they will attempt to beg and/ or steal from you. Generally speaking, Rome is fairly safe. The lady in this vid is just steering you from petty theft can happen in touristic areas. There is much to see in Rome - especially if you like art, history and great ice cream.

replies.textDisplay: The more tourists in a city, the more crowded it is - and the more pickpockets are going to be about. Like she said in the video, tourists are easy targets, and anyone who can afford to be a tourist is rich compared to the pickpockets. You'll hear from all sorts of people how you have to be really careful in such cities, and it's all good advice. It does give an impression that it's much worse than it really is, but fact remains that if you are careless you stand a good chance of being targeted by pickpockets. So be a bit paranoid, and it may not happen to you.
replies.textOriginal: The more tourists in a city, the more crowded it is - and the more pickpockets are going to be about. You'll hear from all sorts of people how you have to be really careful in such cities, and it's all good advice.
